Award.AwardTitle: Natural Attenuation and Enhanced Biodegradation of Methyl tert-Butyl Ether in Anoxic Aquifers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1335824
Max M. Haggblom
Rutgers University

Methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) is an intriguing groundwater pollutant. MTBE is a synthetic chemical with no natural sources and its biodegradation is a challenge to microorganisms. As a consequence of several decades of extensive use MTBE has become one of the most frequently detected groundwater contaminants, requiring remediation due to its persistence in the environment. The overall hypothesis of this research is that long-term MTBE contamination will enrich for anaerobic microbial communities that are capable of utilizing this compound as a source of carbon and energy. Previous research has demonstrated that MTBE degradation can occur under different anoxic conditions, and may be an important process in anoxic environments. However, little is still known about the bacterial species that can utilize MTBE and the biodegradation mechanisms are poorly understood. The research project seeks to elucidate the activity of bacteria that mediate degradation of MTBE in anoxic subsurface environments. Novel microorganisms and their genes responsible for transformation/degradation of MTBE in contaminated aquifers and sediments will be identified in order to develop tools for monitoring natural attenuation and enhanced biodegradation of MTBE in the environment.

Although the use of MTBE as a fuel oxygenate has now been widely banned, problems with contaminated aquifers and drinking water sources persist. MTBE has a very strong turpentine-like taste and smell and can only be tolerated in drinking water at very low levels. The human-health effects of long-term inhalation or oral exposures to MTBE are unknown. There has been an increasing need in the development of effective technologies to remediate MTBE-contaminated sites. Monitoring tools are critical to gaining an understanding of how microbial processes, and thus remediation, are affected by different amendments or other engineering approaches. This project will yield novel approaches to assess and stimulate bioremediation and to document in situ MTBE biodegradation in natural attenuation approaches. A variety of natural processes control plume migration and reduce MTBE concentration. Among these processes, biodegradation is the most effective in reducing the mass of contaminant in the environment in a sustainable way. A key challenge is to accurately assess the efficiency of the remediation techniques in situ. The fundamental microbiological and environmental engineering knowledge gained from the research will fill major knowledge gaps in our understanding of fate and transformation of MTBE in the environment. Implementation of site assessment via emerging environmental molecular diagnostics for MTBE could lead to cost-savings through more sustainable remediation practices, aid choice of site approaches that lead to shortened timelines, and provide information to allow a more rational approach for site remediation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) is a problematic groundwater pollutant. MTBE was initially introduced as an octane enhancer in gasoline and later as fuel oxygenate at higher concentrations throughout the 1990s. As a consequence of several decades of extensive use MTBE has become one of the most frequently detected groundwater contaminants, requiring remediation due to its persistence in the environment. As a synthetic chemical with no natural sources, the biodegradation of MTBE is a challenge to microorganisms. Our overall aim was to identify novel anaerobic bacteria and their genes responsible for the transformation and/or degradation of MTBE in contaminated aquifers and sediments in order to develop tools for monitoring natural attenuation and enhancing biodegradation of MTBE in the environment.  Essentially, we have aimed to decipher which microbes can use MTBE as their food source.


To identify the organisms actively degrading MTBE we have characterized anaerobic cultures enriched with MTBE as their sole carbon source. The cultures were analyzed using stable isotope probing (SIP) combined with molecular analysis of the active bacterial community. The community analysis demonstrated that a member of the Ruminococcaceae in the Firmicutes was predominant in a methanogenic MTBE-degrading culture. The SIP experiments showed sequential incorporation of the 13C labeled MTBE by the bacterial community, with a bacterium most closely related to Saccharofermentans acetigenes identified as the bacterium active in O-demethylation and assimilation of MTBE. The genome of the Ruminococcaceae species was recovered via metagenomics analysis and its metabolic pathways were elucidated. The recovered genome contains genes for many of the enzymes involved in the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway, supporting the hypothesized cleavage of the ether bond and O-demethylation of MTBE followed by degradation via the reductive CoA pathway and acetogenic metabolism by the Ruminococcaceae species.  Acetogenic bacteria in the Ruminococcaceae are hypothesized to initially O-demethylate MTBE via the reductive CoA pathway. Their activity is possibly facilitated by other members of the community, e.g. Syntrophobacter and methanogens, that consume acetate. 

 

The fundamental microbiological and environmental engineering knowledge gained from this research fills a major knowledge gaps in our understanding of fate and transformation of MTBE in the environment. A characterization of the metabolic pathways and identification of the microorganisms responsible for the activity will help us better understand anaerobic MTBE degradation processes in the field and determine biomarkers for monitoring natural attenuation. This knowledge lays the foundation for developing a "toolbox" for site assessment and bioremediation. Monitoring tools are key in gaining an understanding of how microbial processes, and thus remediation, are affected by different amendments or other engineering approaches. The toolbox can include refined molecular tools to monitor bacteria responsible for MTBE degradation that can be used in combination with chemical monitoring, such as compound specific stable isotope analysis. The results of this project will thus play a key role in developing methods for monitoring and assessment of MTBE-contaminated water supplies that are needed to determine whether or not remediation by natural attenuation or enhanced in situ biodegradation are viable options. Implementation of site assessment via emerging environmental molecular diagnostics for MTBE could lead to cost-savings through more sustainable remediation practices, aid choice of site approaches that lead to shortened timelines, and will provide information to allow a more rational approach for site remediation.
